title: William Pitt Peckham
text:
William Pitt Peckham (October 28, 1836 – after 1879 ) was an American businessman from <a href="Neenah%2C%20Wisconsin">Neenah</a>, <a href="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a> who served a single one-year term as a member of the <a href="Wisconsin%20State%20Assembly">Wisconsin State Assembly</a> from <a href="Winnebago%20County%2C%20Wisconsin">Winnebago County</a>.
Background.
Peckham was born October 28, 1836, in <a href="Ballston%20Spa%2C%20New%20York">Ballston Spa, New York</a>. He had a <a href="State%20school">public school</a> education.
In Wisconsin.
He came to Wisconsin in 1855, and settled in Neenah. He became a merchant, invested in the new National Bank of Neenah, and in 1866 became a <a href="stove">stove</a> manufacturer, building the Island City Stove Foundry.
By 1873, he had served as supervisor of the <a href="political%20subdivisions%20of%20Wisconsin%23Towns">town board</a>; president and trustee of the <a href="political%20subdivisions%20of%20Wisconsin%23Villages">village</a>, town <a href="treasurer">treasurer</a> and chief of the <a href="fire%20department">fire department</a>.
In 1873 he was elected for the 2nd Winnebago County Assembly district (the Towns of <a href="Clayton%2C%20Winnebago%20County%2C%20Wisconsin">Clayton</a>, <a href="Neenah%20%28town%29%2C%20Wisconsin">Neenah</a>, <a href="Menasha%20%28town%29%2C%20Wisconsin">Menasha</a> and <a href="Winneconne%2C%20Wisconsin">Winneconne</a>, village of <a href="Menasha%2C%20Wisconsin">Menasha</a> and <a href="Political%20subdivisions%20of%20Wisconsin%23Cities">City</a> of Neenah) as a candidate of Wisconsin's <a href="Reform%20Party%20%2819th-century%20Wisconsin%29">Liberal Reform Party</a>, a short-lived <a href="coalition">coalition</a> of <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrats</a>, <a href="reform">reform</a> and <a href="Liberal%20Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Liberal</a> <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republicans</a>, and <a href="The%20National%20Grange%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20Patrons%20of%20Husbandry">Grangers</a> formed in 1873, which secured the election for two years of <a href="William%20Robert%20Taylor">William Robert Taylor</a> as <a href="Governor%20of%20Wisconsin">Governor of Wisconsin</a>, as well as electing a number of state legislators. He received 1,030 votes, to 771 for Republican P. Yerbeck (incumbent Republican <a href="Thomas%20McConnell">Thomas McConnell</a> was not a candidate). He was appointed to the <a href="standing%20committee">standing committee</a>s on <a href="privilege%20%28legal%20ethics%29">privileges</a> and <a href="elections">elections</a>, and on <a href="medical%20societies">medical societies</a>.
He was not a candidate for re-election in 1874, and was succeeded by Republican <a href="Nathaniel%20S.%20Robinson">Nathaniel S. Robinson</a>.
In 1880 he was a member of Neenah's <a href="board%20of%20education">board of education</a>.
